issues.text: Whether the Additional District Sessions Judge had jurisdiction to try the case, or whether it should have been transferred to and tried by a Special Judge under sections 7 and 10 of the Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1952, given the commitment order was passed before the Act's commencement.

Whether the sanction under section 197 CrPC granted by the Governor-General (Government of India) was valid, including whether it showed exercise of individual judgment and whether the appellant was employed in connection with the affairs of the Federation at the relevant time.

anchor.surface_text: The next argument raised is in regard to the validity of the sanction given by the Government of India to the prosecution of the appellant. This sanction Ext. P-550 purports to have been granted by the Governor-General of India under s. 197 of the Code for the institution of criminal proceedings against the appellant. It has been signed by Mr. S. Boothalingam, Joint Secretary to the Government of India on January 31, 1949.

issues.text: Whether the appellant continued to be employed in connection with the affairs of the Federation (requiring sanction from Governor-General under s.197 CrPC cl.(a)) or had reverted to Assam Government (requiring sanction from Provincial Government under cl.(b)), considering loaned services and leave.

Whether the sanction under section 6 of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947 was validly granted by the Government of India, or whether 'employed in connection with the affairs of the Federation' in cl.(a) means permanently employed (excluding loaned services, falling under cl.(c) requiring Assam Government sanction).

Whether the conviction under s.467 IPC (or alternative under Defence of India Rules r.47(3) r/w r.47(2)) was sustainable, particularly whether accomplice testimony on ante-dating of documents was sufficiently corroborated.

arguments.claim: The Additional District Sessions Judge had no jurisdiction to try the case because the Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1952 had come into operation and the case should have been tried only by a Special Judge under sections 7 and 10.

anchor.surface_text: The first point which Mr. Chari has raised before us is that the Addl. District Sessions Judge had numberjurisdiction to try this case, because at the relevant time, the Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1952 46 of 1952  had companye into operation and the case against the appellant companyld have been tried only by a Special Judge appointed under the said Act.

arguments.court_reasoning: Case not pending before magistrate after commitment order under s.10 CLA; supplementary powers under CrPC s.219 do not mean case pending.

arguments.claim: Even after commitment, the case was pending before the committing magistrate due to power under CrPC s.219 to summon supplementary witnesses.

anchor.surface_text: Mr Chari companytends that though the order of companymitment had been passed, that does number mean that the case had ceased to be pending before the companymitting Magistrate. It is number disputed that once an order of companymitment is made, the companymitting Magistrate has numberjurisdiction to deal with the said matter he cannot either change the order or set it aside.

arguments.court_reasoning: Power is supplementary and does not postulate continuance of jurisdiction; case not pending on merits after commitment.

arguments.claim: Sanction under s.197 CrPC invalid as it does not show Governor-General exercised individual judgment.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Chari, however, attempted to argue that on the face of it, the sanction does number show that the Governor-General granted the sanction after exercising his individual judgment. Section 197 of the companye at the relevant time required that sanction for the prosecution of the appellant should have been given by the Governor-General exercising his individual Judgment,

arguments.court_reasoning: Point not raised earlier or put to witness Boothalingam; cannot be raised first time in Supreme Court.

arguments.claim: At time of sanction, appellant had reverted to Assam Government service, so Provincial Government competent to sanction under s.197 cl.(b).

anchor.surface_text: The next ground of attach against the validity of the sanction is based on the assumption that at the time when the sanctions was  riven, the appellant had ceased to be in the employment of the Government of India and had reverted to the Assam Government.

arguments.court_reasoning: Facts show continued employment with Federation; no reversion order; Assam had no desire to take back until proceedings over.

arguments.claim: Loaned services mean not permanently employed in Federation affairs; falls under s.197 cl.(b), Assam Governor to sanction.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Chari companytends that in the case of the appellant whose services had been loaned by the Assam Government to the Government of India, it companyld number be said that he was a parson permanently employed in companynection with the affairs of the Federation and so, cl.  a  of s. 197  1  would number apply to him at all.

arguments.court_reasoning: Relevant test is employment at time of offence; temporary or loaned employment in Federation affairs means Governor-General competent.

arguments.claim: Appellant permanently employed by Province; loaned services fall under s.6(c) PCA, Assam Government to sanction.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, the appellants case for the purpose of sanction under s. 6 will fall under el.  c  and that inevitably means that it is. only the Provincial Government of Assam which companyld have given a valid sanction under s. 6.

arguments.court_reasoning: 'Employed' in cls.(a),(b) means permanently employed; loaned services under cl.(c), Assam competent.

anchor.surface_text: Having regard to the scheme of the three clauses of s. 6, it is difficult to companystrue the word employed in cls.  a   b  as meaning employed for the time being. The said Words, in the companytext, must mean ,,,permanently employed.

arguments.claim: Accomplice testimony on ante-dating requires independent corroboration; lacking here for s.467.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, in our opinion, the crucial fact on- which the charge under s. 467 is based is deposed to only by accomplice witnesses and their statements are Dot companyroborated by any other evidence on the record.

holdings.text: The Additional District Sessions Judge had jurisdiction to try the case as it was not pending before any Magistrate immediately before the commencement of the Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1952, and section 10 did not apply for transfer to Special Judge.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we are satisfied that the High Court was right in concluding that s. 10 did not apply to the present case and so, the Addl. Sessions Judge had jurisdiction to try the case in accordance with the provisions of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Order of commitment passed on March 1, 1952 before Act's commencement on July 28, 1952; s.219 CrPC provides supplementary power to summon witnesses post-commitment but does not mean case pending on merits before Magistrate.

holdings.text: The sanction under s.197 CrPC granted by Governor-General (Government of India) was valid as the plea regarding individual judgment was not raised earlier and appellant was employed in connection with affairs of the Federation at relevant time.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Plea on individual judgment not put to witness earlier, cannot be raised first in Supreme Court; no reversion to Assam, continued employment with Federation despite loaned services.

holdings.text: Appellant was employed in connection with affairs of Federation for s.197 CrPC purposes even on loaned services from Assam, making Governor-General competent to sanction.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Test is employment at time of offence; temporary/loaned employment in Federation affairs qualifies under cl.(a), no reversion order issued.

holdings.text: Sanction under s.6 Prevention of Corruption Act by Government of India invalid as 'employed' in cls.(a),(b) means permanently employed; loaned services fall under cl.(c) requiring sanction from Assam Provincial Government.

anchor.surface_text: Having regard to the scheme of the three clauses of s. 6, it is difficult to construe the word employed in cls. a b as meaning employed for the time being. The said Words, in the context, must mean ,permanently employed. ... Therefore, the appellants case for the purpose of sanction under s. 6 will fall under cl. c ...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme of s.6 distinguishes permanent employment in cls.(a),(b) from loaned/temporary under cl.(c); authority to remove is lending government.

holdings.text: Conviction under s.467 IPC and alternative under Defence of India Rules unsustainable due to lack of independent corroboration for crucial fact of ante-dating of applications, relying solely on uncorroborated accomplice testimony.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, in our opinion, the crucial fact on- which the charge under s. 467 is based is deposed to only by accomplice witnesses and their statements are not corroborated by any other evidence on the record. ... the finding Of the High Court in respect of the charge against the appellant under s. 467 ... must be reversed...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accomplice evidence on late presentation and ante-dating of applications uncorroborated; no office register or independent proof; tampering in quota register insufficient without identifying who tampered.

holdings.text: No retrial ordered for offences under s.161/165 IPC despite invalid sanction.

anchor.surface_text: We are not inclined to accept this argument. Two facts have weighed in-our minds in coming to the conclusion that a retrial need not be ordered in this case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Protracted 14-year proceedings; case reduced to two accomplice-based instances; ends of justice do not require fresh trial.

Since the order of companymitment in the present case had also been passed before July 28, 1952, the Special Judge held that the case against the appellant must be tried under the provisions of the Criminal Procedure Code and number under the provisions of the Criminal Law Amendment Act

precedents.cited_proposition: Special Judge had no jurisdiction to hear the case because the order of commitment had been passed prior to the passing of the Criminal Law Amendment Act

precedents.citation: Afzelur Rahman v. The King Emperor 1

anchor.surface_text: frivolous prosecution, Vide, Afzelur Rahman v. The King Emperor 1 . That being the object of the section, it is clear that if persons happened to be employed in companynection with the affairs of the Federation, it was the Governer-General who gave sanction and if persons happened to be employed in companynection with the affairs of the State, it was the Governor. What is relevant for the purpose of deciding as to who should give the sanction, is to ask the question where is the public servant employed at the relevant time ? If he is employed in the affairs of the Federation, it must be the Governor-General in spite of the fact that such employment may be temporary and may be the result of the fact that the services of the public servant have been loaned by the State Government to the Government of India.

precedents.case_name: Afzelur Rahman v. The King Emperor
precedents.cited_proposition: object of s 197 1 clearly is to save public servants from frivolous prosecution

anchor.surface_text: The result is, the finding Of the High Court in respect of the charge against the appellant under s. 467 or the alternative charge under the relevant Defence of India Rules must be reversed, his companyviction for the, said offenses set aside and be should be ordered to be acquitted and discharged in respect of those offenses.

outcome.relief_summary: Convictions under s.161 and s.165 set aside due to invalid sanction under Prevention of Corruption Act; conviction under s.467 and alternative charges under Defence of India Rules set aside due to lack of corroboration for accomplice evidence; appellant acquitted and discharged; no retrial ordered
directions: Acquitted and discharged in respect of the offenses
No retrial for offence under s.161

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we are satisfied that the High Court was right in concluding that s. 10 did not apply to the present case and so, the Addl. Sessions Judge had jurisdiction to try the case in accordance with the provisions of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

The result is, the finding Of the High Court in respect of the charge against the appellant under s. 467 or the alternative charge under the relevant Defence of India Rules must be reversed, his companyviction for the, said offenses set aside and be should be ordered to be acquitted and discharged in respect of those offenses.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, in our opinion, the crucial fact on- which the charge under s. 467 is based is deposed to only by accomplice witnesses and their statements are not corroborated by any other evidence on the record. ... the finding Of the High Court in respect of the charge against the appellant under s. 467 ... must be reversed...

Issue on validity of s.6 PC Act sanction granted by GOI directly addresses the sanction requirement for IPC s.165.
Issue of validity of sanction under s.6 PC Act requires determining true nature of 'employed' (permanent vs. loaned services under cl.(c)), central to pith and substance analysis of competence.
Issue i4 questions the validity of the s.6 PCA sanction granted by Government of India, which is addressed by holding h4 declaring it invalid due to permanent employment status.
Issue i5 explicitly concerns the sustainability of conviction under Defence of India Rules r.47(3) r/w r.47(2), which defines concept c10.
Issue questioning sustainability of conviction on accomplice testimony requires application of the concept mandating corroboration of accomplice evidence.
